lead_paragraph: ROTH--Molly Dulcinea, 53, died Wednesday evening, March 9, 2016 in Philadelphia, PA. Molly, a wife, mother, anthropologist, and writer, had abundant intellectual, artistic, and philosophical interests, including languages, literature, theater, film, music, and community development. She approached every topic with curiosity and contributed her vast warmth, humor, and intelligence to every endeavor. Molly, the daughter of Martin and Martha Roth, was born September 25, 1962 in Chicago and grew up in Minneapolis, MN. Molly received a BA in history from Swarthmore College and a PhD in anthropology from the Univ. of Pennsylvania. She published her doctoral research on the Jeli singers of Mali as Ma Parole S'achete: Money, Identity and Meaning in Malian Jeliya (2008). She served in many capacities over the course of a wide-ranging career in non-profits including Interim Director of OIC International, founding Executive Director of the Global Philadelphia Association, Director of Development of the Library Company of Philadelphia, and most recently Director of Development of the American Philosophical Society. She is survived by her parents, her husband Michael W. Hesson, Assistant Professor of Linguistic Anthropology at Temple University, her wonderful daughters Elinor, 16, and Claudia, 10, her sister Jennifer Roth, her brother David Roth, and nieces and nephews: Grey Goodermote, Henry and Faye Monaghan, and Ramona and Leo Roth. Molly is also survived by the many aunts, uncles, cousins, and friends whose lives she touched and enriched. A memorial service is planned for May. Donations in Molly's memory may be made to the American Philosophical Society or to the Bonnie J. Addario Lung Cancer Foundation. 1/3
